Brubeek Featured
For Big Weekend
Final plans for the coming
Spring Big Weekend are drawing
to a close as Dave Brubeck has
been definitely signed for the
Friday night concert. He will be
appearing with another group as

to May 12.
The Friday night concert will
last from approximately eight

place at the Civic Center.

Game Spreads
For many years a popular
spring sport in the eastern part
of the country, lacrosse is played
by more than fifty colleges and
universities, from Dartmouth
College in New Hampshire to
Duke University in North Carolina, and in recent years many
schools and athletic clubs have
started the sport in the West,
especially California. Adapted by
early settlers from an Indian
game, the sport is called the oldest in the United States.
The Johns Hopkins University
has played lacrosse since 1888,
taas won or shared 19 national
championships,

Of the thirty-nine players so

University of Maryland, New

St. John's have two members.
With one member each are Army,

Ottawa and Stevens Tech.
Also included in the Hall will
be displays of major annual lacrosse awards made to schools,
players, and coaches, and exhibits of historical materials of
the game. The University plans
to keep the Hall open to visitors
when the latter is completed in

SC Sets Election
For President
Election activities for the Hopkins student government begin
next week. Between March 11
and April 10, the process of campaigning, assembling, and petitioning will provide much of the
needed excitement so essential
to the balance of student activities.
Beginning on March 11, petitions will be available every week
day at the Barn between 12:15
and 1:00 P.M. A Student Council

Representative will be present in
the Cotillion Board Office to issue the petitions.
Candidates for Student Council President are required to obtain seventy signatures or five
percent of the student body. All
other offices require ten percent
of their respective classes: freshman offices need forty signatures; sophomores, 34; junior, 35.
Assembly Scheduled
There will be an assembly for
the presentation of the Student
Council Presidential candidates
on Tuesday, April 2. The meeting
will be held at Shriver Hall from
four to five. Posters will be
placed throughout the school
especially at crucial positions so
that all students may be kept
informed on the progress of the
elections.
John Barksdale. President of
the freshman class, is directing
publicity for the election. Neal
Grove,'Student Council member,
is general chairman of the
elections.
Voting Lasts 2 Days
The voting begins on April 4
and lasts for two days. This election is for Student Council President. The second to be held
April 10 will decide all other
positions. Ballots will be cast in
Levering Hall from 10-2 and in
the dormitory cafeteria from 5
to 6:30.

Museum Presents
Poetry Discussion
By Pulitzer Bard
Stanley Kunitz, who was
awarded the Pulitzer Prize for
poetry in 1959, will lecture on
"Order and Disorder in Poetry
and the Visual Arts" at The
Baltimore Museum of Art, Sunday, March 10 at 4:00 P.M.
Single admissions are available
at $1.75 for this fourth program
in the Museum's "Sundays at
Four" series. College students will
be admitted at $1.00, said Mrs.
Israel Rosen, chairman for the
lectures which are sponsored by
the Museum's Women's ComMittee.
The poet is noted for his philosophic view which embraces all
the arts. "Ideally", he has said,
"the poet not only defends the
art of his period but tries to put
it into focus in a world view."
Other Awards
His writing has earned him not
Only the famed Pulitzer award
but also a Guggenheim Fellowship; the Amy Lowell Traveling
Fellowship; a Ford Foundation
grant; a National Institute of
Arts and Letters grant: a Garrison medal, Harvard's Oscar
Blumenthal prize and a Levinson
prize among others.
His published verse includes
"Intellectual Things", "Passport
to War", and "Selected Poems,
1928-58". The poet has also published several volumes on authors
of today and yesterday, British
and American authors and an
author's volume especially prepared for young people.
Native of Worcester
A native of Worcester, Massachusetts, Kunitz has taught at
State
Potsdam
Bennington,
Teachers College and has conducted a poetry workshop at
Brandeis University. In addition,
he has lectured at numerous
other colleges and universities.
Among those who have added
their praise to Kunitz' work are
poetess Marianne Moore who
said,"I value his `poetic eye' and
trenchant speech" and Theodore
Roethke who commented, "He
has an acute and agonizing sense
... of what it is to be a man in
this century."
Kunitz is married to the former Elise Asher whose paintings,
watercolors,
her
particularly
have often been successfully exhibited in the Museum's sales
and rental Gallery.

A Broader Study Abroad
The new procedure established for students desiring
to study abroad during the Junior year is a welcomed
addition in the educational policy of the University toward the undergraduate schools. The plan eliminates the
chaotic lack of procedure which has existed for the accreditation of courses taken abroad. At the same time,
it presents an opportunity for students who wish to study
abroad to gain the desired direction which such study
necessitates.
Perhaps the greatest benefit of the plan set forth
by UACSADJY (Undergraduate Advisory Committee on
Study Abroad During the Junior Year) is the freedom it
allows the Hopkins undergraduate to assimilate himself
into the atmosphere of Europe in whatever manner he
desires. The plan is free of any of the paternalistic guides
which have hampered the successful operation of most
of the Junior year study abroad plans of American colleges anti universities.
If Kudos are in order for the establishment of this
plan they must go to Joe Perrotto whose committee (of
similar nomenclature) laid the initial groundwork for
the formation of the faculty's advisory group.

HAIL TO THE DEAN!
Today let us examine that much maligned, widely misunderstood, grossly overworked, wholly dedicated campus figure—
the dean.
The dean (from the Latin Deanere—to expel) is not, as many
think, primarily a disciplinary officer. He is a counselor and
guide, a haven and refuge for the troubled student. The dean
(from the Greek Deanos—to skewer) is characterized chiefly by
sympathy, wisdom, patience, forbearance, and a fondness for
homely pleasures like community singing, farina, spelldowns,
and Marlboro Cigarettes. The dean (from the German Deangemacht —to poop a party) is fond of Marlboros for the same
reason that all men of good will are fond of Marlboros—because
Marlboro is an honest cigarette. Those good Marlboro tobaccos
are honestly good, honestly aged to the peak of perfection, honestly blended for the best of all possible flavors. Marlboro
honestly comes in two different containers—a soft pack which
is honestly soft and a Flip-Top box which honestly flips. You
too will flip when next you try an honest Marlboro, which, one
honestly hopes, will be soon.

here 16' liotdctryereiii yediz
But I digress. We were learning how a dean helps poor,
troubled undergraduates. To illustrate, let us take a typical
case from the files of Dean S
of the University of Y. . .
(Oh, why be so mysterious? The dean's name is Sigafoos and
the University is Yutah.)
Wise, kindly Dean Sigafoos was visited one day by a freshman named Walter Aguincourt who came to ask permission to
marry one Emma Blenheim, his dormitory laundress. To the
dean the marriage seemed ill-advised, for Walter was only 18
years old and Emma was 91. Walter agreed with the dean, but
said he felt obligated to go through with it because Emma had
invested her life savings in a transparent rainhood to protect
her from the mist at Niagara Falls, where they planned to spend
their honeymoon. If Walter called off the wedding, what use
would the poor woman possibly have for a rainhood in Yutala
The wise, kindly dean pondered briefly and came up with a
brilliant answer: let Walter punch holes in the back of Emma's
steam iron. With steam billowing back at the old lady, she
would find a rainhood very useful—possibly even essential.
Whimpering with gratitude, Walter kissed the dean's Phi
Beta Kappa key and hastened away to follow his advice—and
the results, I am pleased to report, were madly successful!
Today Emma is a happy woman—singing lustily, wearing
her rainhood, eating soft-center chocolates, and ironing clothes
—twice as happy, to be candid, than if she had married Walter
. And what of Walter? He is happy too. Freed from his unwanted liaison with Emma, he married a girl much nearer his
own age—Agnes Yucca, 72. Walter ,is now the proud father—
stepfather, to be perfectly accurate—of three fine, healthy
boys from Agnes's first marriage—Everett, 38; Wilhelm, 43;
and Irving, 55—and when Walter puts the boys on a lead and
takes them for a stroll in the park on Sunday afternoon, you
may be sure there is not a dry eye in Yutah.
And Dean Sigafoos? He too is happy—happy to spend long,
tiring hours in his little office, giving counsel without stint and
without complaint, doing his bit to set the young, uncertain
feet of his charges on the path to a brighter tomorrow.
1963 Max Shulman

Swimmers Enter
Conference Meet,
Finish Fourth
The Johns Hopkins Swimming
Club entered the Mason-Dixon
Conference Championships on
March 1-2 and finished fourth
behind Loyola, Old Dominion,
and Catholic U. This marked the
club's second entry into the
finals.
Although the Hopkins men
qualified for the finals in almost
every event, none of them took a
first place. Closest was Craig
Smith, who beat his own conference record for the butterfly,
but finished second by a touch.
Smith, still an underclassman,
can try to regain his crown next
year. Diver and team captain
Don Clewell placed fourth in the
diving, John Mogey came in third
in the 100 yard backstroke, and
the team finished fourth in the
400 yard medley relay.

SC Sets Election
For President
Election activities for the Hopkins student government begin
next week. Between March 11
and April 10, the process of campaigning, assembling, and petitioning will provide much of the
needed excitement so essential
to the balance of student activities.
Beginning on March 11, petitions will be available every week
day at the Barn between 12:15
and 1:00 P.M. A Student Council

Representative will be present in
the Cotillion Board Office to issue the petitions.
Candidates for Student Council President are required to obtain seventy signatures or five
percent of the student body. All
other offices require ten percent
of their respective classes: freshman offices need forty signatures; sophomores, 34; junior, 35.
Assembly Scheduled
There will be an assembly for
the presentation of the Student
Council Presidential candidates
on Tuesday, April 2. The meeting
will be held at Shriver Hall from
four to five. Posters will be
placed throughout the school
especially at crucial positions so
that all students may be kept
informed on the progress of the
elections.
John Barksdale. President of
the freshman class, is directing
publicity for the election. Neal
Grove,'Student Council member,
is general chairman of the
elections.
Voting Lasts 2 Days
The voting begins on April 4
and lasts for two days. This election is for Student Council President. The second to be held
April 10 will decide all other
positions. Ballots will be cast in
Levering Hall from 10-2 and in
the dormitory cafeteria from 5
to 6:30.

Museum Presents
Poetry Discussion
By Pulitzer Bard
Stanley Kunitz, who was
awarded the Pulitzer Prize for
poetry in 1959, will lecture on
"Order and Disorder in Poetry
and the Visual Arts" at The
Baltimore Museum of Art, Sunday, March 10 at 4:00 P.M.
Single admissions are available
at $1.75 for this fourth program
in the Museum's "Sundays at
Four" series. College students will
be admitted at $1.00, said Mrs.
Israel Rosen, chairman for the
lectures which are sponsored by
the Museum's Women's ComMittee.
The poet is noted for his philosophic view which embraces all
the arts. "Ideally", he has said,
"the poet not only defends the
art of his period but tries to put
it into focus in a world view."
Other Awards
His writing has earned him not
Only the famed Pulitzer award
but also a Guggenheim Fellowship; the Amy Lowell Traveling
Fellowship; a Ford Foundation
grant; a National Institute of
Arts and Letters grant: a Garrison medal, Harvard's Oscar
Blumenthal prize and a Levinson
prize among others.
His published verse includes
"Intellectual Things", "Passport
to War", and "Selected Poems,
1928-58". The poet has also published several volumes on authors
of today and yesterday, British
and American authors and an
author's volume especially prepared for young people.
Native of Worcester
A native of Worcester, Massachusetts, Kunitz has taught at
State
Potsdam
Bennington,
Teachers College and has conducted a poetry workshop at
Brandeis University. In addition,
he has lectured at numerous
other colleges and universities.
Among those who have added
their praise to Kunitz' work are
poetess Marianne Moore who
said,"I value his `poetic eye' and
trenchant speech" and Theodore
Roethke who commented, "He
has an acute and agonizing sense
... of what it is to be a man in
this century."
Kunitz is married to the former Elise Asher whose paintings,
watercolors,
her
particularly
have often been successfully exhibited in the Museum's sales
and rental Gallery.

A Broader Study Abroad
The new procedure established for students desiring
to study abroad during the Junior year is a welcomed
addition in the educational policy of the University toward the undergraduate schools. The plan eliminates the
chaotic lack of procedure which has existed for the accreditation of courses taken abroad. At the same time,
it presents an opportunity for students who wish to study
abroad to gain the desired direction which such study
necessitates.
Perhaps the greatest benefit of the plan set forth
by UACSADJY (Undergraduate Advisory Committee on
Study Abroad During the Junior Year) is the freedom it
allows the Hopkins undergraduate to assimilate himself
into the atmosphere of Europe in whatever manner he
desires. The plan is free of any of the paternalistic guides
which have hampered the successful operation of most
of the Junior year study abroad plans of American colleges anti universities.
If Kudos are in order for the establishment of this
plan they must go to Joe Perrotto whose committee (of
similar nomenclature) laid the initial groundwork for
the formation of the faculty's advisory group.

HAIL TO THE DEAN!
Today let us examine that much maligned, widely misunderstood, grossly overworked, wholly dedicated campus figure—
the dean.
The dean (from the Latin Deanere—to expel) is not, as many
think, primarily a disciplinary officer. He is a counselor and
guide, a haven and refuge for the troubled student. The dean
(from the Greek Deanos—to skewer) is characterized chiefly by
sympathy, wisdom, patience, forbearance, and a fondness for
homely pleasures like community singing, farina, spelldowns,
and Marlboro Cigarettes. The dean (from the German Deangemacht —to poop a party) is fond of Marlboros for the same
reason that all men of good will are fond of Marlboros—because
Marlboro is an honest cigarette. Those good Marlboro tobaccos
are honestly good, honestly aged to the peak of perfection, honestly blended for the best of all possible flavors. Marlboro
honestly comes in two different containers—a soft pack which
is honestly soft and a Flip-Top box which honestly flips. You
too will flip when next you try an honest Marlboro, which, one
honestly hopes, will be soon.

here 16' liotdctryereiii yediz
But I digress. We were learning how a dean helps poor,
troubled undergraduates. To illustrate, let us take a typical
case from the files of Dean S
of the University of Y. . .
(Oh, why be so mysterious? The dean's name is Sigafoos and
the University is Yutah.)
Wise, kindly Dean Sigafoos was visited one day by a freshman named Walter Aguincourt who came to ask permission to
marry one Emma Blenheim, his dormitory laundress. To the
dean the marriage seemed ill-advised, for Walter was only 18
years old and Emma was 91. Walter agreed with the dean, but
said he felt obligated to go through with it because Emma had
invested her life savings in a transparent rainhood to protect
her from the mist at Niagara Falls, where they planned to spend
their honeymoon. If Walter called off the wedding, what use
would the poor woman possibly have for a rainhood in Yutala
The wise, kindly dean pondered briefly and came up with a
brilliant answer: let Walter punch holes in the back of Emma's
steam iron. With steam billowing back at the old lady, she
would find a rainhood very useful—possibly even essential.
Whimpering with gratitude, Walter kissed the dean's Phi
Beta Kappa key and hastened away to follow his advice—and
the results, I am pleased to report, were madly successful!
Today Emma is a happy woman—singing lustily, wearing
her rainhood, eating soft-center chocolates, and ironing clothes
—twice as happy, to be candid, than if she had married Walter
. And what of Walter? He is happy too. Freed from his unwanted liaison with Emma, he married a girl much nearer his
own age—Agnes Yucca, 72. Walter ,is now the proud father—
stepfather, to be perfectly accurate—of three fine, healthy
boys from Agnes's first marriage—Everett, 38; Wilhelm, 43;
and Irving, 55—and when Walter puts the boys on a lead and
takes them for a stroll in the park on Sunday afternoon, you
may be sure there is not a dry eye in Yutah.
And Dean Sigafoos? He too is happy—happy to spend long,
tiring hours in his little office, giving counsel without stint and
without complaint, doing his bit to set the young, uncertain
feet of his charges on the path to a brighter tomorrow.
1963 Max Shulman

Swimmers Enter

The Johns Hopkins Swimming
Club entered the Mason-Dixon
Conference Championships on
March 1-2 and finished fourth
behind Loyola, Old Dominion,
and Catholic U. This marked the
club's second entry into the
finals.
Although the Hopkins men
qualified for the finals in almost
every event, none of them took a
first place. Closest was Craig
Smith, who beat his own conference record for the butterfly,
but finished second by a touch.
Smith, still an underclassman,
can try to regain his crown next
year. Diver and team captain
Don Clewell placed fourth in the
diving, John Mogey came in third
in the 100 yard backstroke, and
the team finished fourth in the
400 yard medley relay.

Yale Trophy, symbolic of MAC

The Blue Jays compeleted the
tournament with 44 bout victories while runnerup Stevens
Tech finished with 40 and Lehigh and Muhlenberg tied for
third place with 38 each. Following were Lafayette, 36; Haverford, 31; and defending champion Temple, 26.
All-Around Superiority
The
Jay swordsmen
also
proved superior in both foil and
sabre as the teams of Tom Ahern
and Bill Greenberg in foil, and
Tim Koehler and Sherm Teichman in sabre, racked up eighteen
and sixteen bout victories respectively to carry off the foil
team and sabre team trophies.
Individually, Tom Ahern won
the individual foil title with a
record of 10-2, while Bill Greenberg placed third at 8-4. Ahern
thus becomes the only fencer in
MAC history to win two individual titles in different weapons,
since he won the individual epee
crown last year.
Sabre Team Completes Bout
In sabre, co-captain Tim
Koehler placed fourth on touches over teammate Sherm Teichman after both men finished
with 8-4 records. Co-captain
Tom McNamara, Wade Horsey.
and Fred Eustis contributed six,
four and one epee bout victories respectively to the overall
team total.
To complete the rout, Hopkins
placed four men on the AllConference team — Ahern and
Greenberg on the first string
team, Koehler and Teichman on
the second string team. Jay
coach Dick Oles was elected
MAC All-Conference coach of
the year by his rival coaches.

Tough assignment—but not insurmountable. Today, not only does
every Ford-built car boast self-adjusting brakes (Falcon extra-duty
bus-type wagons excluded), but the design is so excellent that adjustments can be made more precisely than by hand.
This Ford-pioneered concept is not complex. Key to it is a simple
mechanism which automatically maintains proper clearance between
brake drum and lining.
Self-adjustment takes place when the brakes are applied while backing
up. This adjustment normally occurs but once in several hundred
miles of driving. The brake pedal stays up, providing full pedal

reserve for braking,
